title: Before 1 July 2018, will the European Council announce the opening of formal membership negotiations with any candidate countries or designate any new country as an official candidate for membership?
preds: Talks to start next year with Macedonia and possibly Albania as of yesterday: https://www.wsj.com/articles/eu-targets-next-year-for-accession-talks-with-macedonia-after-name-change-1530047432

Macedonia reached a deal with Greece on the name dispute. France is the main country that remains to be convinced. Seems to be an important issue for Germany. https://www.euractiv.com/section/enlargement/news/end-of-macedonias-name-dispute-opens-road-to-eu-talks-and-nato-membership/
Merkel and Macro might discuss this Tuesday. https://www.politico.eu/article/macedonia-new-name-deal-is-only-end-of-beginning/
Adapting to account for closer time distance to census date.

according to this website there is a very good chance.
https://ec.europa.eu/neighbourhood-enlargement/countries/check-current-status_en

The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia

too short of a timeline.  there was also   Turkey, but I won't even bother list it.
Some questions!  Why we bother with such short timelines is beyond me.

Appearing less likely. France's opposition seems quite firm. Germany says it will need the backing of its Parliament.  https://www.politico.eu/article/johannes-hahn-mariano-rajoy-emmanuel-macron-balkan-enlargement-spain-france-upset-brussels-balkan-plans/

The EU would like to take care of this as end of session business before they break , and it helps counter the pr problem of Brexit by giving the appearance that nations are lining up like Bull Frogs at K Mart during a Hurricane waiting on a blue light special on swim fins.

Candidate countries are :  Montenegro, Serbia and Turkey, with ongoing negotiations ; and Albania and Macedonia with whom talks have not opened yet. (Bosnia-Herzegovina and Kosovo have also been identified). 
On February 6th 2018, the UE has pushed to 2025 integration of Serbia and Montenegro.
For Albania and Macedonia, it would be nearer 2030. As for Turkey, tensions being extremely high, adhesion is no longer seriously considered.  Hence : "opening of formal membership negotiations with any candidate countries or designate any new country as an official candidate for membership", when there are already a few countries being stalled on the line, at such short notice, is particularly unlikely. Source (in French) : 
https://www.touteleurope.eu/actualite/les-etats-adherents-et-candidats-a-l-adhesion-europeenne.html
eu has bigger issues with existing membership, can't open to new members
no one on a short list

I admit I haven't read about the topic, but I think it is difficult the Council starts membership negotiations before the end of negotiations about Brexit and in the final year of the Junker Commission.
The lack of suitable candidates notwithstanding, my non-zero probability prediction is somewhat reflecting possible political signalling following Brexit for the EU's growth prospects and priorities.

Seems very unlikely  in this timeframe (yet I am surprised to see so many 0% forecasts, and I don't fully understand what's behind that). Anyway, here is what I've gathered so far: How could this be a yes?
1) any country on the potential candidate list becomes an official candidate (Bosnia and Herzegovina or Kosovo) [1]
2) any country on the official candidate list starts negotiations (Albania or Macedonia). Correct me if I am wrong but Turkey, Serbia and Montenegro seem irrelevant [1]
3) any country not currently an official candidate or a potential candidate becomes an official candidate. (I am not aware of any countries with potential here) When could it happen? The only Council meeting before 1 July is the one at the end of June [2].  Considerations: The Commission has recommended that Albania and Macedonia begin accession talks [3]. From my understanding, this means that it will be on the agenda for the meeting. The current agenda document does suggest something to that effect. So the question is: is there unanimous support in the Council? For Macedonia, the Commission has recommended accession talks for a long time but has been consistently blocked by Greece. For Albania, this is a first.  Macron wants to see reforms before enlargement [3]. There is skepticism in the Netherlands too. [4] I am seeing conflicting signals from Germany in the English press. In general, for Northern European countries enlargement helps feed opposition parties on the far right, which is a concern. On the other hand, enlargement of the EU is becoming an important mechanism to diminish Russia's sphere of influence in these countries. Still, the memories of EU's double dip recession and North-to-South bailouts also linger in many countries, and might be an important factor. This report (EDIT: realized I didn't link it before - see [5]) argues that it is improbable for any of the listed candidates to be ready to join the EU anytime soon, suggesting they have a long way to go. To even begin talks, countries have to demonstrate they have made sufficient progress. Albania continues to have issues with judicial independence and free media. [6] For Macedonia, it seems like they have a ways to go in resolving a dispute with Greece. [7] and quoted below: "The prospects for a Greek-Macedonian deal are nonetheless uncertain. Athens is pressing for changes to Macedonia’s constitution that would eliminate such a threat. Mr Zaev is open to the idea, but any changes will need ratification twice from Macedonia’s parliament. Besides, he wants to bolster the legitimacy of a settlement with Greece by submitting any constitutional changes to a referendum. Clearing all three hurdles will not be easy. Nor should Greek approval be taken for granted. Alexis Tsipras, the leftwing prime minister, spots a chance for glory. Yet his nationalist coalition partners, Greece’s conservative opposition and the Orthodox church are vocal critics of his diplomacy.  Lastly, not all EU governments are keen to open accession talks with Macedonia. At Nato some do not see Macedonia’s entry as a priority. We shall learn more from an EU summit in June and a Nato summit in July. Both events may arrive too soon for a Greek-Macedonian deal. If so, the EU and Nato should resist the temptation to use the setback as an excuse for neglecting the Macedonian question. The Balkans today is too fragile to permit such complacency." [1] https://ec.europa.eu/neighbourhood-enlargement/countries/check-current-status_en
[2] http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/calendar/?filters=2031
[3] https://www.rferl.org/a/european-commission-recommends-membership-talks-with-macedonia-albania/29173244.html
[4] https://exit.al/en/2018/05/07/dutch-mps-albania-is-not-ready-for-opening-negotiations/
[5] https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13501763.2017.1348385?src=recsys
[6] https://www.transparency.org/country/ALB
[7] https://www.ft.com/content/aa60b6cc-4ebb-11e8-9471-a083af05aea7
Definitely not in the time frame. The only possibilities are nowhere close right now.
The EU had mentioned in 2014 that they do not have plans to expand in the next 5 years.
